descript.abstract: Earthquakes is a point theme repersenting earthquakes worldwide. Attribute information includes the magnitude, depth date and intensity of the earthquakes.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf:
Earthquakes are caused by the release of energy in relatively small areas of the earth's crust or upper mantle. Powerful earthquakes are much more rare than weak ones. For example, earthquakes of magnitude 7.0 occur only one-tenth as often as the number of earthquakes of magnitude 6.0.
Two different measurements are commonly used to describe the power of earthquakes: magnitude and intensity. Magnitude is measured on the Richter scale. It is calculated from the amplitude (side-to-side movement) of seismic waves measured at multiple locations, ideally about 100 kilometers away from an earthquake's focus. Seismographs are used to record the information about wave amplitude. The Richter scale is a logarithmic scale where each number has ten times the wave amplitude (and about 31.5 times the total energy release) of the previuos number. The magnitude of the most powerful recorded earthquakes is 8.7.
Intensity measures the effects of an earthquake, especially the effects on people and structures. It is measured by observations of people witnessing the earthquake aswell as an assessment of damages afterward. Intensity is measured on the Mercalli scale, which ranges from 1 to 12. Intensity is influenced by such things as the strength of the earthquake, distance from the epicenter, the kind and density of structures in the local area, local geology, and the time of day. Intensity is valuable for estimating the strength of historical earthquakes which are known by written accounts and other evidence from long ago. However, intensity is not useful for describing earthquakes in uninhabited areas, such as beneath the ocean.

citeinfo.title: Kompiljacija katalogov zemletrjasenij kak zadacha klasterizacii s obucheniem

srcinfo.srccitea: Kompiljacija katalogov zemletrjasenij kak zadacha klasterizacii s obucheniem

procstep.procdesc:
More than 20 catalogs on a compact disc published by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) were used to compile the earthquake data by continents. The author's software program to eliminate duplicate data was used. The program accounts for possible great variation in epicenter coordinates and origin time due to misprints, incorrect conversion of local time into Greenwich time, and so on. The world catalog of earthquakes since the first century A.D. was compiled. For the continents, the catalog samples were done with limitations on minimum magnitude and intensity at the epicenter. The catalog of Antarctica was complemented by other published data.
All the attributes, excluding intensity, are derived from seismograms recorded by devices (seismographs) that detect shifts of bedrock. Today there are more than 1,000 seismic observation stations around the world.
Intensity is measured by using observations from multiple settlements experiencing an earthquake. By using data from several settlements, a map of isoseists (contours of equal intensity) is compiled and intensity at the center is scored.
Earthquake epicenters were selected according to their magnitudes (M) and intensities (I). The lower limit for the size of earthquakes included in the database varies with the density of seismic activity in a region. The limits used in different regions are given below.
Africa -- The database includes earthquakes of M >= 6.0 or I >= 8 north of 30 degrees north latitude, and M >= 5.0 or I >= 6 south of 30 degrees north.
Antarctica -- The database includes seismic events with epicenters south of 40 degrees south latitude. For continental events there is no lower magnitude limit. Earthquakes in other areas of the Antarctic have a lower limit of M = 6.0.
Asia -- The database includes information on earthquakes since the first century A. D. up to the middle of 1993 of M >= 6.0 or I > 8 for the Pacific belt; M >= 5.5 or I >= 8 for the part of the Alpine-Himalayan belt from Belujistan to the Burman arc, the Chinese active zone, and the southern part of the Pamir-Baykal zone; M >= 5.0 or I >= 7 for the western part of the Alpine-Himalayan belt to the north of Lake Balkhash; and M >= 4.0 for the area north of 60 degrees latitude.
Australia and Oceania -- For epicenters within Australia, the database includes earthquakes of M >= 5.0 or I >= 6. To the north and east of the continent (Phillipines, southern Pacific islands, New Zealand, etc.), earthquakes are included with M >= 6 or I >= 7.
Europe -- The database includes information on all European earthquakes from the first century A.D. up to the middle of 1993 of M >= 4.5 or I >= 5 for the Alpine belt (excluding the Balkans), M >= 5.0 or I >= 7 for the Balkans, M >= 5.0 for the Atlantic belt, and M >= 4.0 for the Arctic belt, M >= 4.0 or I >= 5 for other areas. The lower limitation of earthquakes east of 61 degrees longitude is M = 5.5.
North America -- The database includes earthquakes of M >= 5.0 or I >= 7 for most of North America; M >= 6.5 or I >= 8 for the Aleutian Islands, Alaska, Mexico, and Central America; M >= 6.0 or I >= 8 for California; and M >= 4.5 or I >= 5 for northern Canada.
South America -- The database includes earthquakes of M >= 6.0 or I >= 8 for the Andes, M >= 4.5 or I >= 5 for the Caribbean basin, and M >= 5.0 for ocean areas (except M >= 5.5 for the South Sandwich Islands).

procstep.procdesc: Datasets for eacch continent were converted from ESRI coverage to the ESRI shapefile format using the 'copy features' tool and merged into one layer using the 'merge' tool.
